div.sent: God who is love, created man and this earth out of love.
But man committed sin by disobedience.
In course of time, man's sins filled the earth.
But God did not sit idle.
He wanted to save man and this earth, the objects of his love, from sin.
He wanted man to come back to him, just as a kind father wants his wayward son to come back.
Therefore, God sent his Beloved Son Jesus to this earth, so that mankind may be saved from their sins:
Jesus came to this earth to give life to men.
Those who follow Jesus receive life.
Relationship with Jesus is the greatest and the most important thing in man's life.
To believe in Jesus means to accept his ideals wholehearted.
It means to build a personal and healthy relationship with Jesus.
This becomes possible when we go him, know him intimately and follow him.
In this way man can overcome sins and death.
A doctor cures a patient suffering from various illnesses by treatment.
However, more important- than medical knowledge and experience is the doctor's relationship with the patient.
If a patient does not disclose his problems to the doctor clearly, the Doctor can not prescribe the right kind of medicine.
Hence a good relationship between the doctor and the patient is very important.
Jesus came to us as a physician and he still wants to come.
Jesus did much more for us what a doctor does for a patient.
In order to give us life, he has laid down his own life.
Jesus said, I came that they may have life, and have it abundantly.
Jesus came to save us from our sins.
The wages of sin is death, but he came to this earth to save us from death and to give us life.
If we love him and obey his commandments, then Jesus will give us eternal life.
Jesus completed his salvific mission by his suffering and death for mankind.
His suffering, death and Resurrection are his greatest works on our behalf.
These last acts of Jesus are the greatest proof that he is our Saviour and Redeemer.
In this lesson we will learn about the true identity of Jesus as the giver of life.
In a village named Bethany, there was a man named Lazarus who was very sick.
He had two sisters : Mary and Martha.
Jesus loved them very much.
They sent the news of Lazarus sickness to Jesus, so that he could come and heal him.
In order to reveal the glory of God, Jesus set out for Bethany to heal Lazarus.
When he reached Bethany, he was told that it was already four days that Lazarus had died and he had been buried.
People used to think that the body begins to decompose four days after the death.
Many people came to console Martha and Mary.
When Martha heard that Jesus was on his way, she went out to meet him and Mary stayed at home.
Martha said to Jesus, Lord, if you had been here, my brother would not have died.
Jesus said to her, Your brother will rise again.
Martha could not understand what Jesus meant.
So she said, I know that he will rise again in the resurrection at the last day.
Jesus said to her, I am the resurrection and the life;
he who believes in me, though he die, yet shall he live, and whoever lives and believes in me shall never die.
Then he asked Martha, Do you believe this ?
Martha answered, Yes, Lord; I believe that you are the Christ, the son of God, he who is coming into the world.
Having said this, Martha went into the room and called Mary quietly saying, The Teacher is here and is calling for you.
And then Martha and Mary came to Jesus.
Now Jesus had not yet come to the village, but was still in the place where Martha had met him.
Mary fell at his feet, saying to him, Lord, if you had been here, my brother would not .have
She was weeping and those who had come there to console them began to weep.
Jesus was deeply moved in spirit and troubled.
He asked them, Where have you laid him ?
They took Jesus near Lazaxus grave.
Everyone knew, how much Jesus loved Lazarus.
Some of them remembered that Jesus had given sight to the blind.
They kept saying to themselves, he could have saved Lazarus.
Then Jesus, deeply moved again, came to the tomb; it was a cave, and a stone lay upon it.
Jesus told the people to remove the stone.
Martha said to him, Lord, by this time there will be an odour, for he has been dead four days.
Jesus said to her, Did I not tell you that if you would believe you would see the glory of God?
So they took away the stone.
And Jesus lifted his eyes and said, Father, I thank you that you have heard me.
The dead man came out, his hands and feet bound with bandages, and his face wrapped with a cloth.
Jesus said to them, Unbind him, and let him go.
Many who came there, seeing this great miracle, believed in Jesus.
We can learn many things about death and eternal life from this event.
This saying of Jesus: I am the resurrection and the life;
he who believes in me, though he die, yet shall he live, and whoever lives and believes in me shall never die.
the Christian faith in death and eternal life has been proclaimed.
Jesus means to say that whoever lives and believes in him, need have no fear of death.
The eternal life begins with faith.
This eternal life is the experience of heavenly peace, joy and love.
Jesus came in the world to give his life.
But he cannot give us, this life unless we build a relationship of faith and love with him.
Let us try to become good friends of Jesus like Martha, Mary and Lazarus, so that we may gain eternal life.
This eternal life cannot be enjoyed merely by keeping relationship with Jesus, unless at the same time we express it in our relationship with others.
It is through fulfilling our duties towards the poor, the suffering and the downtrodden that we can build close relationship with Jesus.
This has been wonderfully expressed in the accounts of the Last Judgement in Mathew's Gospel.
God is seated on his heavenly throne for the Last Judgment, surrounded by the angels.
In front of him there people from all nations of the world.
They have been divided into two groups.
Just as the shepherd separates the sheep from the goats, so people have men separated.
At the right hand side stood the good people who were humble like the sheep.
God praised them and rewarded them with eternal life in his heavenly Kingdom.
For they had served God through serving men in various ways.
They fed the hungry, gave drinks to the thirsty, shelter to the homeless, clothes to the naked.
When someone was sick or in prison, they went to visit him.
In this way they served people in their needs.
So they asked when they had served the Lord God.
And God answered, You served me when, you served the needy.
Those people are considered true children of God who, inspired by divine love, love and serve others.
The eternal life is for them.
The people at the left hand side were like goats and they received curse and punishment in hell.
For they did not help people in their needs.
They did riot understand when they failed to serve God.
But God said, When you did not do it to least of these, you did it not to me.
So they have to suffer punishment in hell.
A famous writer, Jean Vanier, wrote a story about the believers entering into heaven in his book called The Way of the Pilgrims:
When the pilgrims arrived at the gate of heaven, the angels came to welcome them.
For this reason, the king, i.e., God, invited them to enter into heaven.
There they received form him the crown of glory.
A grave is a sign of death.
After we place the corpse in the grave, we think everything is over.
To our physical eyes it seems to be the case.
But this is not so, when we look at it with the eyes of faith.
Jesus has given us eyes of faith.
So, now we see death as a door to a new life.
It is our faith in Jesus that makes it possible.
Lazarus is a symbol of all of us.
We too will one day be placed in the grave.
But we have nothing to fear.
Jesus will raise the believers back to life.
Jesus and his disciples went out to the Mount of Olives.
Jesus entered the Garden of Gethsemane and started praying.
At a distance his disciples, were sleeping.
Jesus returned to his disciples and asked them to stay awake.
He told them that in a short while he would be betrayed.
Jesus was still speaking when Judas, one of his disciples, arrived.
With him was a large crowd armed with swords and clubs.
They had been sent by the chief priests and the elders.
Judas had given them a signal that the man he kisses would be Jesus.
They should arrest him.
Accordingly Judas went straight to Jesus and kissed him.
Jesus said, Be quick about it, friend.
Then those people arrested Jesus.
One of the disciples got excited, and the drew his sword and struck at the High Priest's slave, cutting off his ear.
But told him not to stop them.
He said, Put your sword back-in its place.
All who take the sword will die by the sword.
Everything is happening according to God's plan.
Otherwise God himself could have protected me.
Every day I sat down and taught in the Temple, and you did not arrest me.
All this happened in order to make what the prophets wrote in the Scriptures come true.
Then all the disciples left him and ran away one by one.
Why didn't he resist them?
Certainly he could have resisted.
Instead we see in this the great humility and love of Jesus.
Moreover, he accepted God's will.
First of all, we notice Jesus attitude towards Judas.
He addressed him as `friend.
Judas betrayed Jesus with a kiss which is the sign of intimate friendship.
Even then Jesus sincerely accepted him as a friend.
He did not rebuke him.
Secondly, people came to arrest him with swords and clubs.
They probably thought they would meet with resistance.
But Jesus proved them wrong.
For he does not depend on swords or earthly power to win over people's hearts:
On the contrary, he depends on God's love and patience.
That is how he finally overcame the world.
Thirdly, he rebuked one of the disciple who drew his sword.
They did not really get to know who Jesus was, even after living with him for so long so intimately.
That is why one of them drew a sword and tried to resist Jesus enemies by cutting off someones ear.
Jesus never carried any arms.
Most of the time the use of arms excites the enemies.
Therefore, Jesus taught his disciples even in this moment of crisis that love is the most powerful weapon which can win over an enemy.
But the disciples failed to understand this and when they were unable to resist, they fled away in fear.
They abandoned their dear Master to the enemies.
We can learn a few lessons from this incident of Jesus's arrest for our practical life.
Judas was one of the , Twelve Apostles.
Just the mere thought is frightening.
They lived with Jesus, heard his sermons, saw him work miracles; and yet one of them became a traitor!
Such seems to be the case all the time.
There is always someone who works against his own people.
We call them traitors.
Mirzafar was the General under Nawab Siraj-ud-Dowla, the last ruler of Bengal.
For this petty self-interest he betrayed his own country and gave over the freedom of Bengal to the British.
Many were like this during our Liberation War.
They are known as razakars and al-Badars.
We certainly cannot and we won't be able to tolerate such traitors.
But Jesus has shown his infinite love and generosity towards them by forgiving Judas.
We too have the experience of being opposed by someone when we try to do something good.
But we should never despair or lose hope.
There is no need to consider them enemies and to be anxious to wipe them out.
We must go on doing what is just, true and beautiful.
Time will come when the traitors or the enemies will repent.
Either they will change, or they will suffer the consequences of their work.
Beginning from Judas, there have been many examples like this.
We became Jesus disciples by our faith in him.
We have been baptized in the love of our Lord Jesus Christ.
So we have to be patient with people like Judas.
We have to resist ourselves from the thought of taking revenge and destroying our enemies.
In imitation of Jesus, we have to try to win over all by our love and forgiveness.
We must leave judgment to God, and we must follow the truth in accordance with God's will.
This will be a proof for us that we have learned from the life of Jesus.
God's gracious providence is beyond our grasp.
In imitation of Jesus, we must entrust our cares, sorrows, pain and difficulties to God.
We can never do anything better than what his divine providence has ordained for us.
He was oppressed, and he was afflicted, yet he opened not his mouth.
Then those who had seized Jesus led him to Caiaphas the high priest, where the scribes and the elders had gathered.
Caiaphas could no longer hold his patience.
He tore his robes and said, He has uttered blasphemy.
Why do we still need witnesses?
You have now heard his blasphemy.
What is your judgment?
They answered in one voice, He deserves death.
Caiaphas then handed over Jesus to them.
They spat in his face, and struck him; and some slapped him saying, Prophesy to us.
Who is it that struck you ?
In this way they falsely condemned Jesus to death.
But Jesus was silent like a humble lamb.
They, however, did not have the courage to sentence Jesus to death.
So on the next day they took counsel against Jesus and led him away and delivered him to Pilate the governor.
If Pilate approves, then they will have no fear of passing death sentence to Jesus.
When Pilate the governor saw Jesus, he asked, Are you the King of the Jews?
He asked this question to Jesus to find out whether he was guilty of sedition.
Jesus answered, You have said so.
At this time the chief priests and the elders started shouting against Jesus accusing him of many - things.
Pilate could not decide what he should do.
So he asked Jesus, Do you not hear how many things they testify against you?
But Jesus gave him no answer.
So Pilate wondered greatly.
Now at the feast of the Passover the governor was accustomed to release for the crowd any one prisoner whom they wanted.
And they had then a notorious prisoner, called Barabbas.
Pilate knew that it was out of envy that the Jewish leaders had delivered him up.
The enemies of Jesus excited the people all the more and demanded that he be sentenced to death.
Pilate again asked them, Do you want me to release for you Jesus or Barabbas?
They all shouted, Barabbas!
Then Pilate asked them what he should do with: Jesus.
They shouted saying, Let him be crucified.
Pilate said, Why what evil has he done?
But they shouted all the more, Let him be crucified.
Pilate was a bit perplexed.
Even though he secretly desired to release Jesus, he was afraid there would be a riot.
So he took water and washed his hands before the crow, saying, I am innocent of this man's blood; see to it yourselves.
And all the people answered, His blood be on us and on our children!
Then Pilate released for them Barabbas, and having scourged Jesus, delivered him to the soldiers.
Then the soldiers of the governor took Jesus into the praetorium, and they gathered the whole battalion before him.
They started making fun of him.
And kneeling before him they mocked, him, saying, Hail.
King of the Jews.
And they spat upon him, and took the reed and struck him on the head.
In this way they mocked him and made fun of him.
Then they stripped him of the robe, and put his own clothes on him, and let him away to crucify him.
Surely we feel pain at seeing this unjust trial, mocking and torture by Jesus's enemies.
But this too reveals to us some of the realities of the world around us.
The Jews believed in God.
They thought they were the chosen people of God.
But when God's salvation came to them through Jesus, they did not welcome it.
Pride and religious fanaticism made them blind.
That is why they put Jesus to an unjust trial.
The condemned Jesus to death under the pretext of safeguarding their religion.
But even in the midst of an unjust trial, mockery and torture, Jesus did not forget that he was the Son of God.
Therefore, he was not afraid to say in the presence of Caiaphas that he was the Son of God.
He also admitted to Pilate that he was the King of the Jews.
He did not hide his true identity out of fear of his enemies and imminent death.
In the eyes of the world his death was a defeat, but in the real sense he gained eternal victory.
This truth will be acknowledged some day.
The victory of the truth is sure and certain, and on that day all people will come to know him and accept him.
They will accept him as their true King.
In our consideration, Pilate is an unjust judge.
For he passed death sentence on a man whom he knew to be innocent, out of craving for power and petty self interest.
It is a greater offence to go against the truth knowingly rather than by ignorance.
Pilate could not avoid his responsibility by merely washing off his hands.
He will be In any circumstance of our life, if we accept the mediation of Christ, everything will be well with us.
And we will be able to look at our enemies with Jesus's eyes of understanding and forgiveness.
As they were driving Jesus to the place where he would be crucified, he could no longer bear the heavy cross.
He fell on the ground again and again, and the soldiers kept torturing him.
They came upon a man of Cyrene, Simon by name; this man they compelled to carry his cross.
They offered him wine to drink, mingled with gall, so that the feeling of pain becomes less.
But when he tasted it, he would not drink it.
And when they had crucified him, they divided his garments among them by casting lots; then they, sat down and kept watch over him there.
Over his head they put the charge against him, which read, This is Jesus the King of the Jews.
Then two robbers were crucified with him, one on the right and one on the left.
Those who passed by derided him, not knowing what they were doing.
Some of them were saying, You who would destroy the Temple and build it in three days, save, yourself.
If you are the Son of God, come down from the cross.
The chief priests, along with the others, mockingly said, He is the King of Israel; he saved others, let him save himself.
Let him come down now from the cross, and we will believe in him.
Some others said, He trusts in God; let God deliver him now, if he desires him; for he said, `I am the Son of God.
And the robbers who were crucified with him also reviled him in the same way.
From 12.00 O'clock, there was darkness over all the land.
This was a very painful prayer of Jesus.
But the people did not understand it.
Jesus addressed God as `Eli in his own language .
So some said, This man is calling Elijah.
But the others said, Wait, let us see whether Elijah will come to save him!
Jesus could not bear any more.
He cried again with a loud voice and yielded up his spirit.
The earth shook and the rocks were split; the tombs were opened, and many bodies of the saints who had fallen asleep were raised.
The centurion and those who were with him, keeping watch over Jesus, were filled with awe, and said, Truly this was the Son of God.
Many women had come there following Jesus, were looking on from afar.
In this episode, first of all we see Jesus carrying a heavy cross.
Jesus had told his disciples that he who wants to follow him must take up his cross and follow him.
Simon of Cyrene was privileged to carry Jesus cross.
We too have to take up our own cross if we want to follow Jesus as his true disciples.
The Cross is the symbol of pain and suffering.
This is what Jesus called bearing the cross.
The burden of Jesus cross will be less, if we carry that cross like Simon.
At the birth of Jesus, the wise Men presented him gifts as to a King, and at his death, his enemies mockingly called him a`King.
This is how God revealed that Jesus is truly the King.
He is the Saviour of mankind, he is the King.
We pray that we too may believe like the centurion that Jesus is the Son of God, he is our Lord and Saviour.
The suffering and the death of Jesus on the cross does not mean defeat.
It may be so in the eyes of the world, but in truth this was Jesus victory.
He carried the burden of the sins of all men and died on the cross.
By laying down his own life, he saved mankind from their sins.
Therefore, this was his greatest and most glorious achievement.
Through his death he revealed God's infinite love for us.
We too can glory this death of Jesus by loving him and living for others.
He showed us his love by accepting suffering; let us show him our love by accepting suffering.
After Jesus breathed his last, it was evening.
But who is to bury Jesus body?
The disciples were not around.
Those who were around did not have the courage.
Finally, a rich man form Arimathea, named Joseph went to Pilate and asked for the body of Jesus.
He was known to Pilate and he was a disciple of Jesus.
Mary Magdalene and the other Mary were there.
They had helped Joseph upto now, and then kept sitting opposite the sepulcher.
Next day, the chief priests and the Pharisees could not rest secure.
Then it will not be possible to unveil their fraud.
So, Pilate let them have a guard of soldiers.
Now they were happy that they could guard the sepulcher as they wanted.
They went and made the sepulcher secure by sealing the stone and setting a guard.
Death is ordained for every man, and no one can avoid it.
So Jesus accepted his death.
After his death we discover this disciple of his; Joseph of Arimathea, whose name is not mentioned anywhere else.
He was not one, of the Twelve, but nonetheless he was a disciple.
Therefore, he had enough courage to come forward after the death of Jesus.
In his Gospel St. Mark says of him, He was a respected member of the Council.
St. Luke says that he was a good and righteous man.
from this we can gather that even though the Jews were so fanatic and pharisaic, Jesus had some faithful and devoted friends among them.
We cannot consider everyone of a race or a nation to be bad by making a generalization.
There are always people who oppose injustice, falsehood and violence.
There were some women who remained loyal and devoted to Jesus till the end.
Just as they were present at the time of his burial, so did they become witnesses of his Resurrection.
Faith and devotion enriches a person's experience, and such experiences bring joy to that person.
Let us now look at the other side; viz., his enemies.
Even after the death of Jesus they were afraid.
With Pilate's permission they had sealed the sepulcher and posted a guard, The Devil has power, but he is always weak.
For truth cannot be suppressed.
Evil persons always try to suppress the truth, and glorify the falsehood.
But the truth of the resurrection from the dead will one day stand by itself.
The victory of the truth is sure and certain, and he power of Satan cannot resist it,
Rabindranath Tagore said this about the suffering and death of Jesus :
Suffering out of love is the crowning glory of renunciation:
it is through love than man overcomes death, and glorifies the power of the soul and its bliss above all things.
There was polish priest whose was Maximillian Kolbe.
In 1939, when Hitler captured Poland, Father Kolbe was taken as a prisoner!
He died in the concentration camp amidst hellish torture and persecution.
One of the prisoners who was released later, said of him, Whatever he had he shared with others, bread, soup, time, etc.
He did everything in a heroic way.
His selflessness could be measured only by his total surrender to God.
One day a high official in the prison kicked him very hard.
Surprised at being kicked he just said, May God forgive you.
Perhaps he is the only one who remained free in this hellist place.
Jesus death is not merely a matter of sorrow for us, it is a matter of joy too.
For through his death Jesus brought us new life and proclaimed the victory of the Truth.
Dear Lord, out of love for us you died for our sins.
Have mercy on us.
Help us to accept this life of love -which you wanted to give to its.
Help us to follow the way of the Cross.
Give us courage to fight for the truth, so that we may be saved.
After the Sabbath, toward the dawn of the first day of the week, Mary Magdalene and the other Mary went to see the sepulcher.
Suddenly there was a great earthquake; for an angel of the Lord descended from heaven and came and rolled back the stone.
Out of fear the guards trembled and became like dead men.
The angel sat on the rock that had been rolled back.
His appearance was like lightning, and his raiment white as snow.
The angel said to the women, Do not be afraid; for I know that you seek Jesus who was crucified.
He is not here; for he has risen, as he said.
Come, see the place where he lay.
The angel also told them that they should go quickly and tell the disciples about the Resurrection of Jesus.
Jesus will meet them in Galilee.
So the women departed quickly form the tomb with fear and great joy, and ran to tell his disciples.
And behold, Jesus met them and said, Hail!
And they came up and took hold of his feet and worshipped him.
Then Jesus said to them, Do not be afraid; go and tell my brethren to go, to Galilee, and there they will see me.
When the women left, the guard could not decide what they should do.
They went into the city and told the chief priests all that had taken place.
The chief priests got frightened.
And if this comes to the governor's ears, we will satisfy him and keep you out of trouble.
So they took the money and did as they were directed.
They spread the rumour around that Jesus disciples stole away his body.
After they received news from the women, Jesus disciples went to Galilee, to the mountain to which Jesus had directed them.
And when they saw the risen Lord, they worshipped him; but some doubted.
And Jesus came near them and said to them, All authority in heaven and on earth has been given to me.
Go therefore and make disciples of all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit.
Teach them to observe all that I have commanded you; and lo, I am with you always, to the close of the age.
The Resurrection is a mystery.
It cannot be understood without faith.
The first proof of Jesus Resurrection is the empty tomb.
Death is the end of mans life.
